awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Statistical Models with Applications to Geoscience
awd_abstract_narration:
In an effort to broaden participation in the geosciences, this 8-week summer Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the Florida Institute of Technology will recruit students from community colleges and minority serving institutions. Eight undergraduate students per summer will be immersed in hands-on learning activities and research projects designed to both encourage them into and prepare them for careers in the geosciences. To accomplish this, participants will first be exposed to basic statistical models and computer programming skills and then will apply those skills to their geoscience related projects. To promote teamwork and esprit de corps, students will work in groups of two in four specific project areas that share a common theme related to a changing climate. The individual projects, which link climate impact on rainfall patterns to water quality and sea level rise with melting glaciers, address key geoscientific problems and issues. Making these connections between projects and disciplines is an important outcome that will be achieved through various activities including workshops, engaging discussion, and mentorship.  Professional development activities include team building, presentation and personal interaction skills, preparing for and applying to graduate school, and career opportunities and options.

This is an 8-week Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the Florida Institute of Technology. This REU Site will recruit underserved and underrepresented students from community colleges and minority institutions. The participating undergraduate students will be immersed in hands-on learning activities and research projects designed to both encourage and prepare them for careers in the geosciences. Eight students per summer in groups of two will work on four research projects with a unifying theme of statistical models with applications to real geoscience problems. Cross-fertilization and connections are important components in geoscience research and synthesizing various scientific disciplines can help to emphasize areas of common interest. Students will work on four diverse projects in this REU program of which climate change forms the nexus. These projects address climate-related impacts involving changes in precipitation patterns, mountain glaciers, benthic communities/coastal estuarine water quality, and ciguatoxins that make fish poisonous. The diverse set of projects integrates accumulated knowledge from individual disciplines and applies that knowledge toward the understanding of connected geoscience processes ranging from the local to global scale. Students will learn basic statistical analysis methods and tools and then implement them using a programming language applied to their geoscience projects. The participants will also learn how to interpret and present their research findings. Professional development activities include team building and personal interaction skills, preparing for and applying to graduate school, and career opportunities and options.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes for Florida Tech NSF REU Site: Statistical Models with Application to Geoscience

Intellectual Merit

The Florida Tech REU site of Statistical Models with Application to Geoscience provided undergraduate students with an immersive research experience that emphasized not only advanced statistical modeling but also foundational data literacy skills essential for solving complex geoscientific problems. Key outcomes include:

  1. Student Research Contributions:
    • Participants applied statistical models to geoscientific challenges, including predicting sea level rise in Florida, analyzing climate impacts on glacier variations, impact of benthic organisms on water filtration, damage estimation due to hurricane, studying the dynamics of coastal erosions, modeling sandstorms in Africa, spatiotemporal analysis of wildfire in California, and predicting the flight rules by weather and environmental factors.
    • Research outputs included 5 published Journal papers, 4 Journal articles in preparation or under review, more than 30 conference presentations in National Conference on Undergraduate Research (NCUR), Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference in STEM, Joint Statistical Meeting (JSM), International Conference on Coastal Engineering (ICCE), and Florida Tech REU Symposium.
  2. Data Literacy and Technical Skill Development:
    • A cornerstone of the program was equipping students with the ability to source, clean, and preprocess data for real-world applications.
      • Participants learned to identify and retrieve geoscientific datasets and satellite imagery from sources like NOAA, USGS, FAA, and NASA.
      • Projects included cleaning datasets to handle missing values, ensuring temporal and spatial alignment of data from disparate sources, and matching resolutions across datasets (e.g., integrating satellite imagery with ground-level observational data).
    • Participants gained significant experience in using programming languages and tools such as R, MATLAB, Python, and QGIS for data manipulation and visualization.
  3. Interdisciplinary Collaboration:
    • The program fostered interdisciplinary research, with students bridging geoscience, statistics, and data science fields. Faculty mentors guided students in applying statistical models and machine learning methods to domains such as glaciology, environmental science, geoscience, hydrology, and atmospheric science, emphasizing the role of robust data preparation in achieving accurate results.

 

Broader Impacts

  1. Increasing Diversity in STEM:
    • The program successfully engaged a diverse cohort, with 66% of participants representing underrepresented groups in STEM fields, including women, first-generation college students, and other underrepresented groups.
    • Outreach efforts targeted institutions with limited research infrastructure, ensuring access to advanced research opportunities for a wide range of students.
  2. Impact on Participants:
    • Post-program surveys indicated that participants developed a strong understanding of the end-to-end research process, from data acquisition to dissemination.
    • Students demonstrated improved skills and knowledge in applying data literacy skills and statistical modeling techniques to real-world problems, with incorporating these skills into capstone projects and subsequent internships.
    • Alumni tracking showing growing interest among participants and several of them pursued graduate studies.
  3. Community and Societal Benefits:
    • Modeling and data-driven insights from participant projects have been further developed and outcomes have been disseminated. The implemented models and methods will be used for improving local water filtration projects in Indian Lagoon River, prediction of socioeconomic impacts of water scarcity due to mountain glacier melts, improving the air flight navigation regarding flight rules, and improving the prediction of the building damages due to natural disasters.
    • Public outreach activities included invitation for attending Florida Tech’s REU Symposium, sharing and presenting the outcomes through more than 30 presentations, and publication of the methods and results in 5 journal papers.
  4. Broader Dissemination of Results:
    • A publicly accessible website of presentations and publications, explaining statistical workflows, is created, enabling researchers and educators to review and replicate the methods.
    • Participant research was showcased at national conferences such as NCUR, ERN, JSM, and ICCE, further promoting the integration of statistical modeling and geoscience.

Conclusion

The Florida Tech REU site of Statistical Models with Application to Geoscience achieved significant outcomes by integrating statistical modeling, data analysis, and machine learning with a strong focus on data literacy. By teaching students to source, clean, and preprocess complex datasets, the program equipped them with skills critical for solving modern geoscientific challenges. These efforts not only advanced the intellectual merit of the research but also ensured broader societal impacts by preparing a diverse cohort of students to become leaders in data-driven geoscience research.
